Hi Alexander, I've added some more thoughts. Please tell me where I might be off track though, I don't want to have you flip-flopping with the implementation based on lack of understanding on my part.

Can you please provide the full `busctl list` and `busctl tree` output here for all relevant connections? That would be very useful context to orient people (me).
Added the busctl tree and full busctl introspect for one console. It's just the same with multiple consoles since they each have their own dbus name.

I have a vague feeling that this is too abstract. Are you proposing that this interface is always exposed regardless of whether a UART mux is present or not? If it's not exposed when a mux isn't present, then I think it should be clear in the name that the interface relates to the mux, e.g. `xyz.openbmc_project.Console.Mux`. If it is always exposed, what's its behaviour when a mux isn't present?

Separately, the interface must first be specified in `phosphor-dbus-interfaces` before it's implemented here, to make sure it's properly debated. You can find the other interfaces specified there also:

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/tree/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Console

The interface can always be present, independent of the existence of a mux.

There is always an active console, and if there is only one console, that one cannot be deactivated, since there is only 'Activate' method without arguments.

So the existence of that interface is harmless and other projects do not have to handle the edge-case where it's there or not there.

I can try to get something merged in phosphor-dbus-interfaces and update here,  keeping this as unresolved for now.
Let's continue this discussion on the [PDI patch](https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/71878).

                                          | mux-index = 0      |

                                               |

| xyz.openbmc_project.Console.host1 +-----+         +-----+ ttyS0 +-----+ UART0 +-----+     |     +-------+
+-----------------------------------+     |         |     |       |     |       |     |     |              
                                          |  obmc   |     +-------+     +-------+     |     |              
                                          | console |                                 | MUX |              
                                          | server  |                   +-------+     |     |              
+-----------------------------------+     |         |                   |       |     |     |

+-----------------------------------+     |         |                   |       |     |     |     |       |

                                               |

Can you please add some discussion of how we configure obmc-console for this hardware setup? I think we need to unpack answers to questions such as:

My questions here really reflect how I'm treating this documentation: I'm using it as a specification for how the implementation should behave, not the other way around.

I don't want to have to reverse-engineer your intentions out of the implementation details of what at one point was a 3000 line patch. Please try to consider your reviewers here.

I do think it would be appropriate to write a design document, as mentioned above.

I'm not suggesting you read all the patches.

Some of them are not even ready yet and may have to be changed depending on the outcome of the iniparser patch and our discussions here. I do not want to waste your time reviewing code that will change anyways.

It is only a first implementation which can be used to experiment with the feature.

However the first two "refactor run_console" and "move main functions into their own files" already stand on their own and can be reviewed.

Also the iniparser patch can already be reviewed since we agreed on using sections to simplify the configuration.

I want to make some forward progress here. Adding another corpse to markdown graveyard (aka design documents) will only further delay this feature.

I'm fine with creating documentation in this repo, since it is close to the code and may actually be updated with time.

> I want to make some forward progress here.

Forward progress happens at the rate at which we can reach consensus. If you want to make some forward progress here, please help me help you achieve that consensus. Consensus comes from the ability to adapt to the needs of others while still achieving our own goals.

My needs, as one of the maintainers of the affected code, are to ensure I'm comfortable with the design, the UX (how the console behaves) and UI (how the APIs are exposed), and eventually how we implement these concerns in the context of the existing code.

Currently, many important points of the design and discussion of their trade-offs are scattered over multiple comments and the implementation. For me this is ineffective as it's difficult to extract a coherent picture. To make forward progress I would like to be able to quickly iterate on all the details and trade-offs of the design in one place, away from the implementation. Doing so away from the implementation allows us to involve other stakeholders where necessary (e.g. maintainers of phosphor-host-ipmid, bmcweb) without dragging them into the weeds, or (yet) having to reshape the implementation as well. Writing down a design will save us from unnecessary implementation and review.

Broadly, OpenBMC uses design documents for this purpose. The CONTRIBUTING documentation outlines how changes should be planned:

https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#planning-changes

Not doing avoidable work by first reaching consensus on a design will make forward progress easier.

> Adding another corpse to markdown graveyard (aka design documents) will only further delay this feature.

From the perspective of OpenBMC's design documents being an up-to-date reflection of the code, yes, they are a markdown graveyard.

But this perspective misses their actual purpose, which is to provide a mechanism and a rallying-point for developing consensus on how the project wants to do something. Storing the result in the docs repo isn't so much for them to forever reflect the code, but to capture why some decisions were made the in the way that they were. They are a historical artifact. Trying to treat them as anything else will likely lead to frustration. They're a collaborative blog post - current at the time of submission, but YMMV beyond that.

Hi Andrew,

as per request, i created the design doc over at

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/docs/+/72125
Thanks, I'll mark this as resolved for now.

I'm a bit wary of `mux-gpio-N` as a concept. I think my ideal approach would be to have a `mux-index` property, which can take an integer value, and then somewhere (maybe not here?) we specify `mux-gpios` which takes one or more GPIO names to look up. The order of GPIOs listed in `mux-gpios` forms the LSB-first bit representation of an N-bit number that bounds the value of `mux-index`. This is inspired by the `i2c-mux-gpio` devicetree binding:

https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/tree/Documentation/devicetree/bindings/i2c/i2c-mux-gpio.yaml?h=v6.10-rc2#n32

I don't think `mux-gpios` should be specified in the config for a given console, as it would then be duplicated (and need to be consistent) across console configs. Really it describes something associated directly with the mux, not the mux's downstream ports. Possibly I'm flip-flopping here, but do we go back to a single config file with sections? Doesn't feel great to require yet-another-file to solve the where-do-we-represent-this problem (in my defense I was trying to prompt some discussions last time before you implemented multi-file scheme, but you've already implemented it 😄)

If we start with sections it may get overcomplicated and the parser would have to be modified. There may need to be an additional level of structure to the 'struct config' to support sections along with the memory-management to ensure everything properly allocated and freed. 

Maybe something like

meta-openembedded/meta-oe/recipes-support/iniparser/iniparser_4.1.bb

would make sense to at least have a standard format and then be able to use some standard dependency instead of hand-coding a parser to support sections. 

For the mux config, we can make it similar as for the i2c-mux-gpio dt binding like you suggested. It will be more familiar to developers who already worked with that.

For the multi-section config file, i can investigate if the 'iniparser' dependency would be suitable.

> Maybe something like
>
> meta-openembedded/meta-oe/recipes-support/iniparser/iniparser_4.1.bb
>
> would make sense to at least have a standard format and then be able to use some standard dependency instead of hand-coding a parser to support sections.

I'm okay if we add something more conventional. We'll need consensus from Jeremy though, and I fear it will lead to a bit of a cascade of work. Configuring obmc-console is already tricky, and I'm a little concerned we'd only make that worse with the conversion.

If we were to change I'd like to make sure documentation for the new config schema is part of that effort. The project really suffers from a lack of clear documentation there, which is compounded by some of the complexity I've already added with the concurrent consoles support.

> For the mux config, we can make it similar as for the i2c-mux-gpio dt binding like you suggested. It will be more familiar to developers who already worked with that.

Thanks. Familiarity is helpful, but I think the more important aspect is we can lean on prior art and the support of others having already thought about the problem. It might be helpful to link to that i2c gpio mux binding document in the documentation for the new properties.

Why would the configuration be more tricky? 

Everything i was proposing in terms of configuration should be backwards compatible to the old config. If we use sections or multiple configuration files,
the config for a single console can probably stay the same.

It would be cleaner to also have a section in case of a single console, but it's not necessary. iniparser can give better error messages on syntax errors in the config file, so it makes it easier for people to configure.

> Why would the configuration be more tricky?

Well, so long as what we're already accepting in the custom config parser isn't less strict than what's allowed by an INI parser, then it should be fine. I just hadn't convinced myself that was the case.

The iniparser patch is open here

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/obmc-console/+/71973

Before creating the patch, i did some manual testing to see how 'iniparser' behaves 
(especially being able to parse config with sections and config without sections).
I did not find any surprising behaviors.

You can try out iniparser in some small program to see if there is any concerns. Or we can add additional testcases.

Looking forward to your review on that patch 👍

> Looking forward to your review on that patch 👍

Thanks. I'll take a look once we've addressed some of the other concerns in the comments here.

I think you need to unpack why it can be represented in static configuration files then? Or are they not static (are we symlinking them and restarting obmc-console-server)?

I assume the mux is always present. Is that the case?

When the blade is present, the configuration file can be used.

When the blade is removed, the console-server can be stopped, or not stopped, depending on how people want to use it. It is not relevant for this implementation.

It will probably not break anything when the service is not stopped.

The stopping of the service and detection of blade removal is out of scope for this patch series.

From my understanding, devicetree represents static hardware. So representing this in devicetree would be a misrepresentation of the system. Devicetree cannot be 'stopped' like some obmc-console-server systemd service.

The mux could be on the blade or the bmc board, i assume it would be on the blade, but not 100% sure. It might not be relevant for the implementation.

> When the blade is removed, the console-server can be stopped, or not stopped, depending on how people want to use it. It is not relevant for this implementation.

> The mux could be on the blade or the bmc board, i assume it would be on the blade, but not 100% sure. It might not be relevant for the implementation.

If the mux is on the blade and the blade is removed at some point, then we can't sensibly continue with a mux-based configuration of obmc-console-server, right?
I literally cannot understand this comment.

If you cannot understand the comment I'd prefer you ask questions to clarify and not just mark it as resolved.

I'm trying to understand what the requirements and constraints are that you're working with, and what you're proposing the behavior of obmc-console-server should be. I was concerned about a what I thought was a conflict and was asking you to help me understand.

To be clear, I'm not trying to suggest you should be representing blades in the (static) devicetree. But I'm also concerned that an obmc-console configuration file, given it is also static, isn't actually doing us a proper service given the pluggable nature of blades.

What are you proposing is exposed by obmc-console-server if one of the blades it is configured for is removed? Or if the mux is on the blade that is removed, then what? Do we continue exposing all the "consoles" even though all the hardware under obmc-console-server is not connected?

It's fine if the answer is "yes", it's just not clear to me what we _want_ to happen.

I'm sorry, marking it as resolved was probably not the right idea.

We already agreed that disconnecting clients is a bad idea. Since that will force other software to re-connect and implement the additional logic.

So everything can stay exposed. I don't see the downside there.
Can you please document the relevant configuration file properties here as well, so people know *how* to configure the behaviour?

Thanks.

Can we unpack here what is printed and why that's necessary?

Also, do you anticipate closing the client connections after deactivation? If so, why, and if not, why not?

I haven't checked your current implementation because I'd prefer to get the documentation right first, but I think there's an opportunity to expose multiple Unix domain sockets, one for each muxed console. That way we would never have to disconnect anyone, rather we would only route data to connections from the active socket (and not to connections from the non-active sockets).

What's printed is the implementation detail.

I would not want to document it as it could change over time and is not meant to be consumed by software. It is just for whoever reads that log.

The print would include a timestamp and indication of connected/disconnected.

The current implementation should not disconnect anyone. Whatever is read from the uart is routed to the active console.

Disconnecting clients seemed too violent for me. Also there is no mechanism to tell them they should reconnect.

> What's printed is the implementation detail.

I don't think it is. It effectively forms an ABI, as it's a behaviour visible to clients. People will end up grepping for the connect/disconnect string. If it's an implementation detail it can change without concern, but given the circumstance, if it changes, it will break the grep. So I don't think it's an implementation detail.

> I would not want to document it as it could change over time and is not meant to be consumed by software. It is just for whoever reads that log.

So I guess that's my point of disagreement.

> The current implementation should not disconnect anyone. Whatever is read from the uart is routed to the active console.

Okay. I think that's reasonable. I was poking at this to understand the plan with the unix domain socket(s) exposed by the server. So we're still planning to have one per (muxed) console with no disconnection, as opposed to one per TTY device and disconnecting clients on switching the mux. Or are we considering a third option?

There is no consideration for any grep. It's not intended for people to build applications based on it.

That's precisely why i did not document the exact string or format, since that would indicate that there was some kind of interface.

Not everything in life has to follow some specification and be documented. Sometimes there is implementation details.


On top of that, specifying some kind of string format would mean that anything connected to the upstream UART could also print that string, effectively bamboozeling any log consumer into thinking that it's e.g. disconnected when it was just whatever is on the other side of that UART, printing some string.

One would wonder what kind of things could happen if then there was indeed log output afterwards. Maybe that application would then 'forget' these logs
until some type of 'console has been connected' string appears again.

Example 1:
System A - uart - mux - console-server - log file - Application B

1. System A prints 'disconnected' type string, from some random application (malicious or accidental)
2. Application B thinks the console is disconnected, pauses logging
3. Important event happens in System A, logs are printed to uart
4. Application B discards these logs, as it thinks the console is in disconnected state
5. People are sad and realize that any random app can print any string and this does not constitute reliable info on connected/disconnected state.
6. People stop relying on undocumented behavior that's most definitely not intended  to form some kind of interface


If there is an actual need to have some structured data on the precise times the mux was switched and any console was connected/disconnected,
this should better be exposed via some separate interface, like additional dbus methods and properties.

That would be out of scope for this patch series.

> There is no consideration for any grep. It's not intended for people to build applications based on it.
>
> That's precisely why i did not document the exact string or format, since that would indicate that there was some kind of interface.
> 
> Not everything in life has to follow some specification and be documented. Sometimes there is implementation details.

In my mind an implementation detail is a detail that's not visible to the user, usually hidden behind an abstraction. Injecting data into the stream that was not sent by the other side of the console isn't that. Just because you choose to believe that it's an implementation detail that doesn't make it so.

However, I appreciate that this is all quite tempting.

I'm interested in Jeremy's input here.

in latest revision, added some documentation about the log message, and a disclaimer that it's not some kind of API. I hope everyone can be happy with that. 

I do not want to make it some fixed format that then cannot be changed in the future.
What is printed? And why?

The print is good for logging purposes. Any client or log file should have that information. 

Otherwise it would get very confusing for someone reading the logs when there's a chunk missing from the host boot logs since someone switched the mux to BIC UART or something else.

It should be transparent to readers of the log and any clients that they have been connected/disconnected. If the console is disconnected, it will be helpful to have that fact as the first thing in the log file. 

Otherwise people will wonder "where is all the logs, the software must be broken!".

As to what's printed that's implementation detail.

> As to what's printed that's implementation detail.

See the discussion above.
Acknowledged
